_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: Aqua Ammonia solution was inadvertently pumped into a Caustic Soda storage tank.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Plan is the 2018 Updated Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Univar USA, Inc. (Univar) branch located at 3950 NW Yeon Avenue, Portland, Oregon (the Branch).



ERM-West, Inc. (ERM) prepared this Plan on behalf of Univar to satisfy the requirements of the Federal Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions in the Federal Code of Regulations (40 CFR Part 68). The RMP registration required under Section 68.160 of the Federal regulations is included in Appendix E.



Univar is a wholesale chemical distributor serving a number of U.S. industries. Founded in 1924, Univar supplies the food industry, chemical compounders, pharmaceuticals, mining, forest products, oil and gas producers, electronics, coatings and many other key industries with the chemical raw materials and support services required to produce or refine products used in numerous end-use markets.



Some of the products stored and handled by the Branch are subject to the Federal RMP regulations.  A key requirement of this program is the preparation and submission of a RMP.  The Federal EPA prescribes the content of the RMP.



The latest 5-year update to the Federal RMP for the Branch was submitted to the USEPA in September 2012.  The current required 5-year update included the following modifications to the program:



?    Removed regulated substances that are no longer handled onsite in quantities exceeding the regulatory limits:  formaldehyde; 

?    Increased quantities of hydrofluoric acid.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Univar's accidental release prevention program covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the Branch, which demonstrates the facility's commitment to reducing the potential for accidental releases.  It is the Branch's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. 



This program includes provisions and requirements for

the key elements listed in Section 1.4.



The Stationary Sources and the Regulated Substances Handled



The Branch's primary activities encompass the blending, repackaging, bulk and warehouse storage of industrial chemical raw materials and products, and their distribution via Univar's fleet of trucks.  



The following branch processes are the subject of this Plan and hereafter are referred to as the covered processes:



?    Process #1 - Warehousing Operations (Container Storage and Distribution): aqua ammonia (less than 44% by weight).

?    Process #2 - Bulk Loading and Repackaging Operations (Tank Storage & Container Filling and Blending):  aqua ammonia (less than 44% by weight). 

?    Process #3 - Warehousing Operations (Container Storage and Distribution): hydrofluoric acid (less than 59% by weight).



The table below includes the Branch's regulated substances handled onsite that exceed the Federal RMP quantity thresholds. 



Table ES1:    Maximum Intended Inventory of Regulated substances



Chemical Name        CAS Number Maximum Inventory (lbs.)

RMP Program Level   Covered Process

Aqua Ammonia         7664-41-7  35,000     

Federal RMP 2        Warehousing Operations

Aqua Ammonia          7664-41-7  120,000

Federal RMP 2        Bulk and Repackaging Operations

Hydrofluoric Acid     7664-39-3  15,000

Federal RMP 2        Warehousing Operations



All three Covered Processes are in the Program Level 2 Prevention Program.



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The Branch has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68.  The Branch's three covered processes (#1 - Aqua Ammonia Warehousing Operations, #2 - Aqua Ammonia Bulk Operations, and (#3 - Hydrofluoric Acid Warehousing Operations) described in Section 1.3 were designed and constructed in accordance with applicable codes and ordinances in effect at the time of construction. 



S

ection 4.0 describes the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at the Branch.



Five-Year Accident History



Univar has not had an emergency involving the covered processes that caused deaths, injuries, or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place within the last five years. 



Emergency Response Program



In the event of an emergency involving regulated substances, Univar developed a written emergency response plan to handle and address accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The emergency response plan includes adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.



This Plan is shared with local emergency responders who have access to branch personnel (and up--to-date phone numbers).  The Branch responds to minor incidents but will call in professional emergency responders in the event of all other incidents.



Local emergency responders, such as the fire department, are invited and encouraged to visit and familiarize themselves with the products and facilities.  Joint emergency exercises are conducted when possible.



For more detail see Section 5.0.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Recommendations to further reduce the likelihood and/or severity of accidental releases of the three control processes at the Branch were generated during the February 2018 PHA.
